original_data.question: A 54-year-old man presents with the acute onset of seizures and hallucinations. The patient’s wife says that he had been on a camping trip a few months earlier to study bats but otherwise has not traveled recently. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, managed medically with hydralazine and enalapril. The patient’s condition rapidly deteriorates, and he passes away. An autopsy is performed and a histologic stained section of the brain is shown in the image. Which of the following receptors are targeted by the pathogen most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?

model_response:
The patient’s condition is consistent with a diagnosis of rabies, which is transmitted by the bite of a rabid animal, typically a bat, dog, or fox. The pathogen is the rabies virus, which is a member of the Rhabdoviridae family. The rabies virus is a bullet-shaped, enveloped, single-stranded, negative-sense RNA virus. The rabies virus infects a wide range of animals, including birds, but most commonly affects carnivorous or omnivorous animals, such as dogs, cats, skunks, foxes, raccoons, and bats. The rabies virus is transmitted from the infected animal to humans typically by a bite, which transmits the virus through saliva. The virus then replicates in striated and/or ganglionic tissue, particularly the salivary glands and the brain. The virus can also be transmitted from the infected animal to humans via contact with its saliva, such as through mucosal surfaces of the eyes, nose, or mouth. Once the virus enters the body, it can disseminate to the central nervous system (CNS) through retrograde neural transmission within the dorsal root ganglia. The rabies virus infects many different cell types, but it has a particular tropism for the neurons of the CNS and the salivary glands. The rabies virus is transmitted from host to host by an infected animal’s biting behavior. The virus replicates in striated muscle tissue and then spreads to the CNS and salivary glands. The virus can also be transmitted trans-placentally from infected animals to their offspring. The rabies virus is a neurotropic virus that replicates in the cytoplasm. The virus attaches to the host cell through the attachment (C) protein on the virus surface. The virus then enters the cell through endocytosis. The virus then uses the viral RNA polymerase to transcribe the viral RNA into mRNA, which is used for translation of viral proteins. The viral nucleocapsid proteins are produced first, followed by the production of the viral matrix proteins. The viral matrix proteins are important for the assembly of the virion. The viral matrix proteins are followed by the production of the viral glycoproteins, which are important for host cell attachment and cell-to-cell fusion. The final viral proteins produced are the viral RNA polymerase and the matrix protein, which are important for viral replication. The virus then enters the cell through endocytosis. The virus then uses the viral RNA polymerase to transcribe the viral RNA into mRNA, which is used for translation of viral proteins. The viral nucleocapsid proteins are produced first, followed by the production of the viral matrix proteins. The viral matrix proteins are important for the assembly of the virion. The viral matrix proteins are followed by the production of the viral glycoproteins, which are important for host cell attachment and cell-to-cell fusion. The final viral proteins produced are the viral RNA polymerase and the matrix protein, which are important for viral replication.

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Having a severe and rapid onset of symptoms with short duration.

Clinical or subclinical disturbances of cortical function due to a sudden, abnormal, excessive, and disorganized discharge of brain cells. Clinical manifestations include abnormal motor, sensory and psychic phenomena. Recurrent seizures are usually referred to as EPILEPSY or "seizure disorder."
Subjectively experienced sensations in the absence of an appropriate stimulus, but which are regarded by the individual as real. They may be of organic origin or associated with MENTAL DISORDERS.
Living outdoors as a recreational activity.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.

A work that reports on the results of a research study to evaluate interventions or exposures on biomedical or health-related outcomes. The two main types of clinical studies are interventional studies (clinical trials) and observational studies. While most clinical studies concern humans, this publication type may be used for clinical veterinary articles meeting the requisites for humans.
Order of mammals whose members are adapted for flight. It includes bats, flying foxes, and fruit bats.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.

Persistently high systemic arterial BLOOD PRESSURE. Based on multiple readings (BLOOD PRESSURE DETERMINATION), hypertension is currently defined as when SYSTOLIC PRESSURE is consistently greater than 140 mm Hg or when DIASTOLIC PRESSURE is consistently 90 mm Hg or more.
Provision of diagnostic and/or therapeutic treatment.
A direct-acting vasodilator that is used as an antihypertensive agent.
An angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor that is used to treat HYPERTENSION and HEART FAILURE.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
A state of being, such as a state of health.
In an declined condition.
Postmortem examination of the body.

The part of CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM that is contained within the skull (CRANIUM). Arising from the NEURAL TUBE, the embryonic brain is comprised of three major parts including PROSENCEPHALON (the forebrain); MESENCEPHALON (the midbrain); and RHOMBENCEPHALON (the hindbrain). The developed brain consists of CEREBRUM; CEREBELLUM; and other structures in the BRAIN STEM.

Description:A characteristic representing a single file reference that contains two or more views of the same dosage form of the product; in most cases this should represent front and back views of the dosage form, but occasionally additional views might be needed in order to capture all of the important physical characteristics of the dosage form. Any imprint and/or symbol should be clearly identifiable, and the viewer should not normally need to rotate the image in order to read it. Images that are submitted with SPL should be included in the same directory as the SPL file.

A protein located on the cell surface, or in the cytoplasm, that binds to a specific signaling factor, such as a hormone, antigen, or neurotransmitter, causing a conformational and functional change in the receptor molecule. The ligand-bound receptor then alters its interaction with target molecules, which leads to changes in cellular physiology through modification of the activity of one or more signal transduction pathways.
An agent of disease; a disease producer.
A description of the physiological status of a patient.
